newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel -- ready for tax compromise with German SPD.
newsitem.headline: Waigel -- ready for tax compromise with German SPD.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said on Thursday he was ready to reach a compromise with the opposition Social Democrats (SPD) at talks on key tax reforms which will resume next week.
But Waigel told reporters he was not prepared to abandon the overall strategy of the coalition government to cut taxes in a bid to attract job-creating investment to Germany.
He also said it was vital in the interests of German workers that a deal is struck before the summer holidays.

Talks on Waigel's package of 30 billion marks in income and corporate tax cuts are due, after a hiatus, to resume next Tuesday after Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed to an SPD demand that he take part in person.
SPD leader Oskar Lafontaine has also called for a cut in social insurance charges for workers from this summer in addition to big tax cuts for average earners at the start of next year.

But Waigel said social security reforms should be mapped out first before bringing cuts in contributions into the tax debate. "The SPD must be ready to cooperate on the reforms of social security and pensions as well as in cutting labour costs," he said.
Waigel was speaking to reporters after telling a savings bank conference here that recent economic setbacks would not stop Germany qualifying for European monetary union.
